story_headline: Rep. Jordan believes Trump will run in 2024
story_copy: GOP representative Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) said he believes former President Trump will run in 2024. The Congressman made the comment during an interview on Sunday, in which he also said he is going to do everything he can to help Trump win.‚Äù If he wins, and that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm for,‚Äù Jordan said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been for that. Since he left on January 20, I wanted him to run in 2024. I think he‚Äôs going to. I think he is the right candidate.‚ÄùThe Republican said he doesn‚Äôt think January 6 will impact Trump‚Äôs chances and added that the American people know he will fight for them. Jordan also predicted America is going to be ‚Äúso much better off‚Äù if Trump is GOP presidential nominee in 2024 and wins.Trump has made remarks over recent months expressing openness to another run for the presidency in 2024. Jordan recalled the Trump administration‚Äôs use of a whiteboard to¬†catalogue¬†the fulfillment of Trump‚Äôs campaign promises.‚ÄúWe have never had a president who did more of what he said he would do than President Trump,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúI remember early on when I was in the White House they were in the West Wing in one of the offices. They had a whiteboard on the wall and literally they had every single policy and every single promise that President Trump made to the American people in the campaign of 2016. They were literally just checking them off as he did them.‚ÄùWondering where "Leave White House in 7 months" is on Bannon's whiteboard pic.twitter.com/O7UvFtA7y1‚Äî Chris Lu (@ChrisLu44) August 18, 2017In a @TPUSA straw poll today at their summit in Tampa, young conservatives overwhelmingly selected Trump as their choice for president if he launched a re-election bid.DeSantis was a distant second. pic.twitter.com/q4Pl9iPNro‚Äî Julia üá∫üá∏ (@Jules31415) July 24, 2022Jordan‚Äôs remarks come as recent polling indicates Trump would be the front runner for the GOP nomination if he were to launch a bid for the White House.
image_caption: Rep. Jim Jordan on Capitol Hill in Washington. (AP Photo/Evan Vucci, File)

story_headline: Lawmakers warn of emerging biochemical weapons
story_copy: Lawmakers warn of emerging biochemical weaponsSenator Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, looks over papers during a Senate Armed Services hearing to examine the nominations at the Capitol Hill, on Thursday, July 21, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mariam Zuhaib)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:45 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Lawmakers are warning that submitting samples of DNA to private companies may hand over valuable information to America‚Äôs adversaries. Sites like 23andMe could pose immense national security risks.At a recent Aspen Security Summit, Army veteran and Democrat Rep. Jason Crow (D-Colo.) warned America‚Äôs enemies, including Russia and China, are developing biochemical weapons that could target specific people. Crow added, researchers are using DNA data provided to private companies to tailor the weapons to that genetic information. However, he lamented adversaries can get this information easily and without much of a fight.‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt have a discussion about this without talking about privacy and the protection of commercial data because expectations of privacy have degraded the last 20 years,‚Äù Crow explained. ‚ÄúYoung folks actually have very little expectation of privacy, that‚Äôs what the poll and the data shows. And people will very rapidly spit into a cup and send it in to 23andMe and get really interesting data about their background and guess what? Their DNA is now owned by a private company that can be sold off with very little intellectual property protections or privacy protections.‚ÄùAdditionally, Republican Sen. Joni Ernst (R-Iowa) said the threat of a biochemical attack won‚Äôt just hit humans specifically, but also the food supply. She stressed, America‚Äôs adversaries could weaponize diseases that have already plagued the agriculture sector to kill off animals and plants used for food.‚ÄúSo not necessarily those specific human targets with a particular type of weaponized biological weapon, but also if we look at food security and what can our adversaries do with biological weapons that are directed at our animal agriculture, at our agricultural sector,‚Äù Ernst explained.Meanwhile, Army Gen. Richard Clarke claimed bad actors have been quick to use other chemical weapons with relative ease. He cited alleged uses of chlorine and mustard gas being used in Iraq and Syria by ISIS. Gen. Clarke warned even these weapons do not need complex training in order to use them.ÔªøIn the meantime, the congressmen urged their colleagues to adopt legislation, which could bolster protections for Americans‚Äô personal information. This included healthcare, DNA and consumer patterns. Additionally, they stressed the need to add food security in the realm of national security in order to put more attention on America‚Äôs food supply chain.
image_caption: Senator Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, looks over papers during a Senate Armed Services hearing to examine the nominations at the Capitol Hill, on Thursday, July 21, 2022, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mariam Zuhaib)
more_news: ¬†Man Who Attacked Lee Zeldin Arrested On Federal ChargesTOPICS:23andMeagricultureAspen Security Summitbiochemical attackbiochemical weaponsChinaDNAfood supplyHealthHEALTHCAREintellectual propertyJason CrowJoni ErnstNational SecuritynewsOANOANNpoliticsPRIVACYRichard ClarkeRussia SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: Oak Fire near Yosemite National Park forces thousands to evacuate
story_copy: Oak Fire near Yosemite National Park forces thousands to evacuateFirefighters mop up hot spots while battling the Oak Fire in the Jerseydale community of Mariposa County, Calif., on Monday, July 25, 2022. They are part of Task Force Rattlesnake, a program comprised of Cal Fire and California National Guard firefighters. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 10:53 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Thousands of firefighters are battling a rapidly moving wildfire, which continues to burn near Yosemite National Park. The Oak Fire erupted in Mariposa County, California on Friday and has scorched more than 15,000 acres with zero containment.Governor Gavin Newsom (D) has declared a state of emergency for the county as thousands of people have been forced to evacuate their homes. The Oak Fire has become the largest wildfire in the state so far this season.A view of the Oak Fire burning east of Modesto and Merced. It began Friday around 2:30pm near Highway 140 by #Midpines going towards Yosemite.9,500 acres have burned according to Cal Fire. Several structures have been destroyed with 2,000 more in danger.  üî• üëÄ #oakfire pic.twitter.com/UqPLmtdOHJ‚Äî 209 Times (@209TimesCA) July 24, 2022Cal Fire described the blaze as ‚Äúexplosive‚Äù as the fire destroyed several homes and damaged critical infrastructure. Around 2,000 firefighters are battling the Oak Fire using aircraft and bulldozers amid tough conditions, which include steep terrain, scorching temperatures and an ongoing drought.Oak Fire burns thousands of acres near Yosemite in California pic.twitter.com/DiE1likSiF‚Äî Insider News (@InsiderNews) July 25, 2022This comes as firefighters are making progress on the Washburn Fire, which is burning within Yosemite. Governor Newsom has declared a state of emergency for Mariposa County and the Red Cross has established its main evacuation center at an elementary school. Red Cross officials said they are doing their best to provide a safe space as residents hold on to hope amid fear and uncertainty.
image_caption: Firefighters mop up hot spots while battling the Oak Fire in the Jerseydale community of Mariposa County, Calif., on Monday, July 25, 2022. They are part of Task Force Rattlesnake, a program comprised of Cal Fire and California National Guard firefighters. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

story_headline: Dr. Anthony Fauci defends vaccine mandates, says COVID jab ‚Äòvery good‚Äô at stopping severe diseases
story_copy: Dr. Anthony Fauci defends vaccine mandates, says COVID jab ‚Äòvery good‚Äô at stopping severe diseasesFILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Dec. 1, 2021. \Fauci, the government‚Äôs top infectious disease expert, says he plans to retire by the end of President Joe Biden‚Äôs term in January 2025. Fauci, 81, became director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in 1984 and has advised seven presidents. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:49 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022White House Chief Medical Adviser, Dr. Anthony Fauci has continued to defend COVID-19 vaccine mandates. In a recent interview, he was asked why vaccines are still mandated in many places when he himself was quoted as saying that everyone would come into contact with COVID and most would contract it anyway.Fauci said vaccines, particularly boosters, prevent progression of the disease to hospitalization as the reason for the continued push.Fauci, who tested positive for the virus twice, also praised his Paxlovid regimen as he said it gave him a relatively mild disease. Meanwhile, the President‚Äôs physician said Joe Biden‚Äôs COVID symptoms are almost completely resolved. Dr. Kevin O‚ÄôConnor gave the update Monday in a letter to Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre.President Trump gets #COVID:‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the end of the world!‚Äù Fauci and Biden get COVID:‚ÄúNo big deal.‚Äù‚Äî Rep. Jim Jordan (@Jim_Jordan) July 25, 2022O‚ÄôConnor said the President is experiencing nasal congestion and hoarseness, but other than that his pulse, blood pressure, respiratory rate and temperature remain normal. Biden completed his fourth treatment of Paxolvid and will continue taking the medication as planned. He will also continue to isolate according CDC recommendations.According to reports from governments around the world, people who received the COVID vaccines are suffering far more injuries and deaths than those who didn‚Äôt. One America‚Äôs Pearson Sharp has more.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, Dec. 1, 2021. \Fauci, the government‚Äôs top infectious disease expert, says he plans to retire by the end of President Joe Biden‚Äôs term in January 2025. Fauci, 81, became director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in 1984 and has advised seven presidents. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh, File)
more_news: ¬†First Responders Still Undergoing COVID MandatesTOPICS:Anthony FauciCOVIDCOVID-19mandatesPaxlovidPearson Sharpvaccine mandatesVaccines SHARETWEETPINSHARE

story_headline: J6 Committee ‚Äòprepared to contemplate‚Äô subpoenaing Ginni Thomas
story_copy: J6 Committee ‚Äòprepared to contemplate‚Äô subpoenaing Ginni ThomasFILE ‚Äì Virginia ‚ÄúGinni‚Äù Thomas, wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, arrives to watch Amy Coney Barrett take the Constitutional Oath on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, on Oct. 26, 2020. The House Jan. 6 committee said Sunday, July 24, 2022, it will interview more former Cabinet secretaries and is prepared to subpoena conservative activist Virginia ‚ÄúGinni‚Äù Thomas as part of its investigation. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:00 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.) suggested the January 6 Committee could subpoena Ginni Thomas. During an interview with CNN Sunday, the Wyoming republican said the panel is ‚Äúfully prepared‚Äù to consider a subpoena for Thomas who is the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas.Cheney added, a subpoena would only come if Thomas did not testify before the panel voluntarily. The Democrat-led committee requested she testify last month over alleged communications with former Trump administration officials regarding the 2020 election.‚ÄúThe committee is engaged with her counsel,‚Äù said Cheney. ‚ÄúWe certainly hope that she will agree to come in voluntarily, but the committee is fully prepared to contemplate a subpoena if she does not. I hope it doesn‚Äôt get to that. I hope she will come in voluntarily.‚ÄùICYMI: Rep. Liz Cheney on Ginni Thomas, wife of Justice Clarence Thomas: "The [1/6] committee is engaged with her counsel. We certainly hope that she will agree to come in voluntarily, but the committee is fully prepared to contemplate a subpoena if she does not." pic.twitter.com/qGV3W0FslK‚Äî The Recount (@therecount) July 25, 2022Previous reports suggested Thomas was eager to appear before the panel, but her lawyer later said there was ‚Äúno sufficient basis‚Äù to make her testimony relevant.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Virginia ‚ÄúGinni‚Äù Thomas, wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, arrives to watch Amy Coney Barrett take the Constitutional Oath on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, on Oct. 26, 2020. The House Jan. 6 committee said Sunday, July 24, 2022, it will interview more former Cabinet secretaries and is prepared to subpoena conservative activist Virginia ‚ÄúGinni‚Äù Thomas as part of its investigation. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, File)

story_headline: Irish govt. targets farmers with ‚ÄòGreat Reset‚Äô goals
story_copy: Irish govt. targets farmers with ‚ÄòGreat Reset‚Äô goalsA combine harvester at the middle of a wheat field harvesting crops. (Representational Photo via AP)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:49 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022The Irish government is reportedly advancing the ‚ÄòGreat Reset‚Äô agenda in the nation‚Äôs agricultural sector. According to The Times, Ireland plans to impose new carbon emissions standards on farmers seeking to reduce co2 by 28 percent.Irish officials say the plan to crackdown on farm emissions comes in line with EU environmental standards and it will require a decrease in the use of heavy farm machinery such as harvest combines. This comes after farmers in the Netherlands began protests against their government‚Äôs crackdown on nitrogen emissions.Irish farmers say green regulations are hurting their business. Tim Cullinan, the President of the Irish Farmers Association, commented on the matter.‚ÄúIf we have a reduction in what we‚Äôre doing, well obviously that‚Äôs going to effect the viability of farmers,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúSo as it is at the moment, 30 percent of our farmers are viable. So, what we want to achieve here is to get a lot more of our farmers viable. So, it‚Äôs just trying to get that message through.‚Äù¬†The @IFAmedia says a 30% emissions target could cost tens of thousands of jobs. #BKNT #ClimateChange https://t.co/EaLGHhyUGX‚Äî Newstalk Breakfast (@NTBreakfast) July 25, 2022Farmers have asserted that environmental standards undermine food security, but EU governments appear to be unfazed by the threat of mass starvation.
image_caption: A combine harvester at the middle of a wheat field harvesting crops. (Representational Photo via AP)

story_headline: Gov. Hogan: GOP gubernatorial nominee victory was result of collusion
story_copy: Gov. Hogan: GOP gubernatorial nominee victory was result of collusionFILE ‚Äì Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan talks to reporters, April, 4, 2022. Stunning new revelations about former President Donald Trump‚Äôs fight to overturn the 2020 election have exposed growing political vulnerabilities just as he eyes another presidential bid. (AP Photo/Brian Witte, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 9:26 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Governor Larry Hogan doubled down on his opposition to Maryland‚Äôs Republican gubernatorial nominee and his potential successor Dan Cox. In an interview Sunday, Hogan analyzed the possibility of Maryland not having a Republican governor after his term is done.His comments came after he already said he would not be endorsing Cox who emerged as the winner of the Republican primary. Hogan said Cox‚Äôs win was the result of a conspiracy, while also asserting he will not win in the general election.‚ÄúWell it was kind of unprecedented collusion between the Democratic Governor‚Äôs Association and Donald Trump,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúAnd both of them were promoting conspiracy theory of believing kind of a nut job and the DGA, I think, spent about $3 million‚Ä¶it was a win for the Democrats, it‚Äôs a big loss for the Republican Party and we have no chance of us saving that governor‚Äôs seat.‚ÄùCongratulations to @DanCoxEsq on winning the Republican Governor Primary!  Cox will be a great addition to the Republican leadership in Maryland. pic.twitter.com/IYv09olG73‚Äî GOP (@GOP) July 20, 2022Cox will face off against Democrat Wes Moore in November‚Äôs general election.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan talks to reporters, April, 4, 2022. Stunning new revelations about former President Donald Trump‚Äôs fight to overturn the 2020 election have exposed growing political vulnerabilities just as he eyes another presidential bid. (AP Photo/Brian Witte, File)

story_headline: Schiff urges Biden DOJ to probe Trump over J6 clashes
story_copy: Schiff urges Biden DOJ to probe Trump over J6 clashesRep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., listens as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol continues to reveal its findings of a year-long investigation, at the Capitol in Washington, Monday, June 13, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 8:01 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 24, 2022Congressman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) said Biden DOJ should open a formal investigation with Donald Trump over the January 6 protest. In an interview on Sunday, Schiff claimed that the evidence allegedly collected by Democrat-run committee led him to believe Trump may be connected to clashes at the Capitol.This after Schiff promoted the debunked Russia hoax for several years now. The Congressman stated that the panel is still examining possible links between former President Trump and far-right extremist groups, including the Proud Boys and Oath Keepers, members of which have been charged for their roles in the attack. He said Trump should be prosecuted over the Capitol protest.‚ÄúThat remains an ongoing part of our investigation,‚Äù Schiff voiced. ‚ÄúWe have certainly shown some links between the president, the key advisors like Roger Stone and Mike Flynn, and elements of these white nationalist groups, but that component of our investigation continues.‚ÄùDonald Trump‚Äôs incitement of the mob and refusal to stop the violence will be remembered as the worst dereliction of duty by a president of the United States in modern history.‚Äî Adam Schiff (@RepAdamSchiff) July 22, 2022The hearings have ramped up the pressure on the Justice Department to pursue charges against Trump and Schiff said he hopes the department is ‚Äúwatching carefully.‚Äù He hopes that they understand the implications of what the panel is presenting.‚ÄúI think we really need to think about what we‚Äôve demonstrated already,‚Äù he expressed. ‚ÄúAbout the president‚Äôs knowledge that the election wasn‚Äôt stolen and his response and his intent. To me that is most graphically demonstrated when he told top Justice Department officials basically to just say the election was stolen or just say it was corrupt and that he would take care of the rest. Those kind of pieces of testimony, they‚Äôre directly on the president‚Äôs knowledge and intent.‚ÄùHis claims have been debunked by Republicans who said no weapons have been used by January 6 protesters, while most of the violence was committed by Antifa activists and Capitol Police Officers against rally participants.
image_caption: Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., listens as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol continues to reveal its findings of a year-long investigation, at the Capitol in Washington, Monday, June 13, 2022. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

story_headline: Pres. Trump leads the pack in TPUSA 2024 straw poll
story_copy: Pres. Trump leads the pack in TPUSA 2024 straw pollSydney Kinne, left, and Janae Kinne, of Orlando, Fla., answer questions from a reporter outside the Tampa Convention Center during the Turning Point USA Student Action Summit, Saturday, July 23, 2022, in Tampa, Fla. (AP Photo/Phelan M. Ebenhack)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 3:05 PM PT ‚Äì Sunday, July 24, 2022A straw poll suggested young conservatives favor President Trump over Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis (R). The poll taken at the Turning Point USA Student Action Summit was released on Sunday, where Trump overwhelmingly took the lead at 78.7 percent. However, 19 percent said they would vote for Ron DeSantis and one percent for South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem (R). Former Vice President Mike Pence (R-Ind.) came in last with just .3 percent.On Saturday, Trump spoke at the TPUSA summit and teased a 2024 run saying he ‚Äúmay just have to do it again.‚Äù He also told the crowd ‚ÄúIf we are going to save our country we have to get to work immediately‚Äù and ‚Äúwe have to reclaim America.‚Äù‚ÄúIf I had stayed at home, if I had announced that I was not going to run, the persecution of Donald Trump would immediately stop,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs what they want me to do. And you know what? I don‚Äôt have any chance of doing it.‚ÄùOur Student Action Summit isn‚Äôt just about our big name speakers! It‚Äôs about encouraging and celebrating with all the incredible @TPUSA activists who are fighting on their campuses for their voices to be heard! pic.twitter.com/EZl3xrL12l‚Äî TPUSA South Central (@SC_TPUSA) July 23, 2022Other polls taken at the summit revealed that 92.7 percent of attendees disapprove of the Republican establishment in Washington. Over 73 percent of participants said they are not confident that the Republican party effectively communicates to younger voters.Meanwhile in a different poll, students were asked who the most difficult Democrat to defeat for president in 2024 would be and California Gov. Gavin Newsom came out on top at 30.3 percent. Former First Lady Michelle Obama came in second with 13.6 percent followed closely by 10.5 percent for Hillary Clinton and 10.3 percent for Bernie Sanders (D-Vt.).Vice President Kamala Harris and New York Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D) came in last with 7.9 percent and 5.9 percent respectively.
image_caption: Sydney Kinne, left, and Janae Kinne, of Orlando, Fla., answer questions from a reporter outside the Tampa Convention Center during the Turning Point USA Student Action Summit, Saturday, July 23, 2022, in Tampa, Fla. (AP Photo/Phelan M. Ebenhack)

story_headline: Biden‚Äôs officials doing damage control ahead of recession numbers
story_copy: Biden‚Äôs officials doing damage control ahead of recession numbersBrian Deese, Assistant to the President and Director of the National Economic Council, speaks during a meeting where President Joe Biden appeared virtually with his economic team in the South Court Auditorium on the White House complex in Washington, Friday, July 22, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022The Biden administration is downplaying concerns of a recession ahead of this week‚Äôs GDP numbers that are expected to show an economic downturn. In a statement Monday, the White House questioned how economists determine a recession while alleging the US economy is ‚Äútransitioning‚Äù from ‚Äò‚Äùfast growth‚Äù to steady and slow growth.Biden economic advisor Brian Deese: ‚ÄúWe are seeing a slowing [economy], that is not only expected but necessary, as we operate through this transition.‚Äù pic.twitter.com/9wiJH8NP4Y‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 25, 2022The US GDP shrank 1.6 percent in the first quarter and the Atlanta Fed expects it to fall another 2.1 percent in the second quarter. However, President Biden‚Äôs officials are claiming two quarters of negative growth does not indicate a recession although it does. The Bureau of Economic Analysis will release its advance estimate of second quarter GDP on Thursday, July 28.Biden economic advisor Jared Bernstein downplays the slowing economy and recession concerns as ‚Äúsemantics‚Äù pic.twitter.com/4AcVyILrae‚Äî RNC Research (@RNCResearch) July 25, 2022Meanwhile, former Treasury Secretary and Obama administration economic adviser Larry Summers blames a possible upcoming recession on high government spending.¬† In an interview Sunday, Summers said the Biden administration borrowed too much money over the past two years. As a result, the US national debt surged above $30 trillion.‚ÄúI think there is a very high likelihood of recession when we‚Äôve been in this kind of situation before,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúRecession has essentially always followed when inflation has been high and unemployment has been low.‚ÄùSummers said the US economy may face high inflation and no growth for a while.¬† The US government is set to release second quarter GDP figures later this week and if it is negative that would mean the country is officially in a recession.
image_caption: Brian Deese, Assistant to the President and Director of the National Economic Council, speaks during a meeting where President Joe Biden appeared virtually with his economic team in the South Court Auditorium on the White House complex in Washington, Friday, July 22, 2022. (AP Photo/Andrew Harnik)

story_headline: Ore. Antifa thugs attack biker event, get beaten
story_copy: Ore. Antifa thugs attack biker event, get beatenNEW YORK, NY ‚Äì APRIL 11: People hold Antifa flags at Trump Tower to counter protest the ‚ÄúWhite Lives Matter‚Äù march and rally on April 11, 2021 in New York City. (Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 6:20 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Oregon bikers took out the trash after a local branch of Antifa declared war on the motorcycle club. According to reporting by the Post Millennial and several Twitter accounts, Antifa activists besieged the Honky Tonk Bar in Salem, Oregon last week which began their feud with bikers.Breaking: #Antifa members including Clifford Eiffler-Rodriguez (in blue top & hat) gathered for a direct action to shut down the Honky Tonk bar in Salem, Ore. but were met by a group of bikers. One of the Antifa begins macing people before retreating. pic.twitter.com/08i6D89Oza‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 16, 2022At the time, bikers were holding the Hero Appreciation Day at the bar which Antifa deemed as a ‚Äúracist‚Äù and ‚Äúwhite supremacist‚Äù gathering. When Antifa showed up in black bloc, their numbers were very few. Still, they used a megaphone to draw attention to the gathering across the street from the bar. Eventually, several patrons made their way over to confront the demonstrators. Arguing turned into shoving, mace was deployed by an Antifa member and then the group retreated away from the establishment entirely. Antifa activists are now making threats against bikers online.It‚Äôs not like Antifa is unfamiliar with physical confrontation. Per Andy Ngo, one of the organizers of the demonstration at the Honky Tonk Bar was arrested in 2021 after allegedly hitting a female police officer. Ngo claimed another in attendance plead guilty the week before for doing over $164,000 in damages to a courthouse.Salem #Antifa member Clifford Phillip Eiffler-Rodriguez (in blue), a convicted fraudster, was one of the organizers of today's failed direct action against the Honky Tonk Bar. He was previously arrested at a violent protest last year where he allegedly hit a female officer. pic.twitter.com/WB6hxgMsbT‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 17, 2022The attempted #Antifa attack on the Honky Tonk Bar in Salem, Ore. ended in humiliation for Antifa members today. They lacked the numbers to launch assaults & were met by a group of angry women & bikers. Antifa also appeared to have now ignited a feud with a motorcycle club. pic.twitter.com/lSKfgKCyDI‚Äî Andy Ng√¥ üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@MrAndyNgo) July 17, 2022White Rose of the Willamette Valley used its Twitter account to complain after Salem Police didn‚Äôt protect their fellow Antifa members during the confrontation. It said Free Souls and ‚Äúother uniformed security‚Äù both ‚Äúattacked and injured community members peacefully protesting‚Äù without supplying details or other evidence. Unlawful Whatever on Twitter claimed ‚Äúone of ours‚Äù was hospitalized from the fight, retweeting a different person claiming ‚ÄúSalem police literally backed away‚Äù when the Free Souls came out to confront them.Free Souls MC and other uniformed security attacked and injured community members peacefully protesting the far-right event at Honky Tonk tonight engaging in physical assault and bear spray attacks. Again @cityofsalem @SalemPoliceDept is this what you accept here?‚Äî White Rose Of the Willamette Valley (@WhiteRoseOfSal1) July 16, 2022Oregon biker groups including the Free Souls Motorcycle Club warned Antifa to stay away from their venues and events going forward.
image_caption: NEW YORK, NY ‚Äì APRIL 11: People hold Antifa flags at Trump Tower to counter protest the ‚ÄúWhite Lives Matter‚Äù march and rally on April 11, 2021 in New York City. (Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images)

story_headline: Same-sex marriage needs 10 GOP senators for codification
story_copy: Same-sex marriage needs 10 GOP senators for codificationFILE ‚Äì Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, speaks during hearing on the fiscal year 2023 budget for the FBI in Washington, May 25, 2022. A bipartisan group of senators, including Collins, released proposed changes July 20, to the Electoral Count Act, the post-Civil War-era law for certifying presidential elections that came under intense scrutiny after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and Donald Trump‚Äôs effort to overturn the 2020 election. (Ting Shen/Pool Photo via AP, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 11:24 AM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Forty-seven House Republicans joined every Democrat in backing codification of same-sex marriage, in turn, sending the bill to the Senate. Now in the upper chamber, the bill, which would repeal the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, codify interracial marriage and give legislative backing to the Supreme Court‚Äôs Obergefell decision, could face an uphill battle to the 60 votes needed for passage.All 50 Democrats have announced their support for gay marriage with the onus falling squarely on 10 Republican senators to join them and send the bill to President Joe Biden‚Äôs desk. Sen. Susan Collins of Maine has led Republican efforts to codify gay marriage while working closely with the Senates first openly lesbian member, Democrat Tammy Baldwin of Wisconsin, to try and secure the 10 GOP votes. Alaska‚Äôs Lisa Murkowski, Ohio‚Äôs Rob Portman and North Carolina‚Äôs Thom Tillis have also announced their support.If you are a Senator who supports marriage equality then you will support our bipartisan Respect for Marriage Act to protect this freedom and right for same-sex and interracial marriages. Let's stand together and protect the progress we have made.‚Äî Sen. Tammy Baldwin (@SenatorBaldwin) July 20, 2022However, even staunch conservatives are getting on board with the bill as Wisconsin‚Äôs Ron Johnson has announced his intention to vote ‚Äòyes.‚Äô He said that while he thinks the bill is unnecessary because overturning gay marriage would disrupt people‚Äôs lives in a way overturning abortion did not, he wouldn‚Äôt oppose its passage.‚ÄúUnlike Roe v. Wade, this pretty well is settled law from the standpoint that people have relied on that and if you overturn it, that‚Äôs a big part of Stare Decisis, it would disrupt a lot of people‚Äôs lives,‚Äù Johnson stated. ‚ÄúRoe v. Wade was about affecting people in the future‚Ä¶as I look at that piece of legislation from the House right now, I don‚Äôt see any reason why I should oppose it.‚ÄùDespite this, opposition still runs steep among some parts of the Senate Republican caucus. South Carolina‚Äôs Lindsey Graham has said that he would continue to support the Defense of Marriage Act passed in 1996 with majority support among both parties in both chambers and signed by Democrat President Bill Clinton.The Republican Whip in the Senate, Texas‚Äô John Cornyn, who‚Äôs fresh off writing the latest anti-Second Amendment legislation with Democrats, has said he feels the issue is an unnecessary distraction because it‚Äôs already settled law.‚ÄúI I think it‚Äôs a contrived issue because the Supreme Court‚Äôs decided the issue, so I don‚Äôt see any reason for the Congress to act,‚Äù he stated.Ted Cruz, Texas‚Äô other Republican senator, along with a few others are also expected to vote ‚Äòno.‚Äô The rest of the caucus remains cagey about giving a direct answer on where they sit. Iowa‚Äôs Joni Ernst has said she needs time to review the legislation and Utah‚Äôs Mitt Romney believes the bill is unnecessary, but is looking into it.Louisiana‚Äôs Bill Cassidy didn‚Äôt say if he would support the bill, but did tell reporters he was amazed they fall for distractions by the Democrats listed off a litany of pressing issues facing the country from a wide open border to record inflation. He said the whole thing was to shift the media‚Äôs attention from those issues.With most Republicans not giving a firm answer one way or the other, it could be a bill with an unknown status until it comes to the floor for a full vote by the body. If it passes, Biden has said he will sign it the moment it gets to his desk. However, even if the bill fails, same sex marriage will still be the law of the land for the foreseeable future with Republican legislators and Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh asserting the Obergefell decision isn‚Äôt going anywhere anytime soon.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Sen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, speaks during hearing on the fiscal year 2023 budget for the FBI in Washington, May 25, 2022. A bipartisan group of senators, including Collins, released proposed changes July 20, to the Electoral Count Act, the post-Civil War-era law for certifying presidential elections that came under intense scrutiny after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and Donald Trump‚Äôs effort to overturn the 2020 election. (Ting Shen/Pool Photo via AP, File)

story_headline: Dem. Rep. Luria: Liz Cheney should be face of GOP
story_copy: Dem. Rep. Luria: Liz Cheney should be face of GOPFILE ‚Äì Rep. Elaine Luria, D-Va., speaks as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol holds a hearing at the Capitol in Washington, Thursday, July 21, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:49 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Democrat Rep. Elaine Luria said she wants Liz Cheney to be the face of the Republican Party. Speaking to Meet the Press on Sunday, the Virginian said she has become good friends with the Wyoming Rep. since working together on Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs (D-Calif.) January 6 committee. According to Luria, even if Cheney loses her primary her voice is vital for the future of the GOP.‚ÄúI admire Liz Cheney,‚Äù Luria said. ‚ÄúI have been friendly with her ever since I came to Congress, even before we served on this committee together. I think that if she doesn‚Äôt come through this primary, come back to Congress, there are so many things that she could do in the future for our country.‚ÄùWhile Democrats promote Cheney, Republicans have repudiated the Rep. to the highest degree. The Wyoming Republican Party has formally censured her and no longer recognizes her as a member of the party.‚ÄúHer voice is absolutely needed,‚Äù Luria added. ‚ÄúAnd I think she‚Äôs one of unfortunately, a very small number of people who need to be the face of the Republican Party in the future. I would love to get back to where we had two political parties that debate on issues and facts and not lies. I really hope that Liz Cheney will continue, but I don‚Äôt want to speculate. She‚Äôs said herself she doesn‚Äôt know what her future plans will be.‚ÄùTwo profiles in courage: Liz Cheney & Elaine Luria. Both willing to put country before party even though it may cost them reelection in November. We need more people with this level of commitment to democracy in Congress, not fewer.‚Äî Joyce Alene (@JoyceWhiteVance) July 22, 2022In an extremely rare move, the RNC and Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) have thrown their support behind Rep. Hageman (R-Wyo.) which put the former vice president‚Äôs daughter on the outs.
image_caption: FILE ‚Äì Rep. Elaine Luria, D-Va., speaks as the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol holds a hearing at the Capitol in Washington, Thursday, July 21, 2022. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, File)

story_headline: WH: WHO announcement a ‚Äòcall to action‚Äô for global community
story_copy: WH: WHO announcement a ‚Äòcall to action‚Äô for global communityNEW YORK, NY ‚Äì SEPTEMBER 29: Ethiopia Minister of Foreign Affairs Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus speaks on stage during the Unleashing Women‚Äôs Economic Opportunites session during the 2015 Clinton Global Initiative at the Sheraton New York Times Square Hotel on September 29, 2015 in New York City. (Photo by JP Yim/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:01 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022The White House agreed with the World Health Organization‚Äôs decision to declare the spread of Monkeypox a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. They expressed that it is a ‚Äúcall to action.‚Äù In a statement Saturday, the Director of the White House Pandemic Preparedness Office Raj Panjabi claimed that an international response was essential to stop the spread. The World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus made the decision to declare the PHEIC after two separate deliberations with an emergency committee.‚ÄúA coordinated, international response is essential to stop the spread of Monkeypox,‚Äù Panjabi said. ‚ÄúIt will protect communities at greatest risk of contracting the disease and combat the current outbreak.‚ÄùWith the tools we have right now, we can stop #monkeypox transmission and bring this outbreak under control. It‚Äôs essential that all countries work closely with affected communities to adopt measures that protect their health, human rights and dignity.pic.twitter.com/DqyvRtB8w2‚Äî Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (@DrTedros) July 23, 2022According to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, as of Friday there are close to 2,900 cases of Monkeypox that have been reported in the US. The states with the highest case counts are in New York, California, Florida, Illinois and Georgia. More than 16,000 cases have been reported in 75 countries and territories.‚ÄúSo in short, we have an outbreak that has spread around the world rapidly through new modes of transmission about which we understand too little and which meets the criteria in the international health regulations,‚Äù he voiced.The White House also maintained that the current administration has implemented a complex strategy to combat Monkeypox outbreaks in the US. They are dramatically scaling the procurement, distribution and production of vaccines.Today, OSTP released the Monkeypox Research Priorities to accelerate operational research and evidence to strengthen the ongoing global monkeypox outbreak response. https://t.co/VuwhaqDxHD‚Äî White House Office of Science & Technology Policy (@WHOSTP) July 21, 2022The Department of Health and Human Services¬†announced earlier this month¬†another 144,000 doses of the Jynneos vaccine would be distributed in addition to the more than 41,000 doses given out already to combat the virus, which is generally spread through contact directly with body fluids, rashes and scabs and prolonged face-to-face contact.
image_caption: NEW YORK, NY ‚Äì SEPTEMBER 29: Ethiopia Minister of Foreign Affairs Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus speaks on stage during the Unleashing Women‚Äôs Economic Opportunites session during the 2015 Clinton Global Initiative at the Sheraton New York Times Square Hotel on September 29, 2015 in New York City. (Photo by JP Yim/Getty Images)

story_headline: Biden‚Äôs Commerce Secy: China tariffs may be lifted
story_copy: Biden‚Äôs Commerce Secy: China tariffs may be liftedCommerce Secretary Gina Raimondo at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune/Time Inc)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 1:10 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo confirmed that the Biden administration is considering lifting tariffs on China. In an interview Sunday, Raimondo said officials are looking at potential labor implications of lifting Trump-era tariffs on China. She added that tariffs could be lifted if it helps bring down inflation and alleviate supply chain problems.The Secretary¬†also praised Biden‚Äôs so-called green agenda despite concerns it may further cripple US manufacturing. Despite¬†an analysis by the Peterson Institute for International Economics¬†that lifting tariffs on some Chinese-made products would save households hundreds of dollars, Biden is concerned about the support of unions in making this decision.‚ÄúThere are potential labor implications,‚Äù Raimondo stated. ‚ÄúOne thing about this president is he will never do anything that he thinks will hurt workers in America or union workers in America.‚Äù¬†Labor unions are actively campaigning against dropping tariffs on China with multiple groups filing an official comment to the Office of the US Trade Representative earlier this month to advocate for the tariffs to stay in place. Trump imposed numerous tariffs on China during his time in office. The former president believed that trading practices with the country were unfair to the US. The Biden administration has kept many of the tariffs in place despite indicating some of the policies need to be changed.‚ÄúThe labor market is now extremely strong,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis is not an economy that‚Äôs in recession, but we‚Äôre in a period of transition in which growth is slowing. And that‚Äôs necessary and appropriate, and we need to be growing at a steady and sustainable pace.‚ÄùThe Commerce Secretary herself advocated for dropping some of the tariffs, but there is no clear timeline on when the president will make a decision on the issue. Biden‚Äôs thinking could also be impacted by the midterm elections where union support is a big help to Democrats in a year where Republicans are expected to pick up multiple seats.The President is still weighing whether or not to lift tariffs off of China. The action potentially could have an impact on US inflation. @POTUS has said he plans to talk to China's Xi within days. https://t.co/mQq2r8jBU4‚Äî Margaret Brennan (@margbrennan) July 24, 2022Raimondo voiced that the Biden administration may restrict the exports of US technology to prevent it from falling into the wrong hands.
image_caption: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Washington, D.C. (Photo by Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Fortune/Time Inc)

story_headline: NYC Mayor Adams announces student debt relief program for mental health professionals
story_copy: NYC Mayor Adams announces student debt relief program for mental health professionalsFILE ‚Äì Mayor Eric Adams speaks during a graduation ceremony at Madison Square Garden, on July 1, 2022, in New York. (AP Photo/John Minchillo, File)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 12:02 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022New York City Mayor Eric Adams announced the launch of a student debt relief program for mental health professionals. During a press conference Sunday, Adams said the Behavioral Health Loan Repayment Program was funded by an anonymous $1 million donation and is designed to help attract and retain healthcare providers.Learn more about the @NYCHealthSystem Behavioral Health Loan Repayment Program (BH4NYC) at https://t.co/ijsBkIiUon. Applications are now open! https://t.co/3JF0OOQxes‚Äî Mayor's Office of Community Mental Health (@MentalHealthNYC) July 25, 2022Under the program, New York City health and hospitals will offer psychiatrists, nurse practitioners, psychologists and licensed clinical social workers who work three years in the hospital system between $30,000 and $50,000 of debt relief.¬† Applications for the program begin Monday and run through November 25 and will reopen in January for a second round.Mayor Eric Adams Makes Health and Education Related Announcement:

story_headline: Sen. Cotton: No due process in J6 show trial
story_copy: Sen. Cotton: No due process in J6 show trialWASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì OCTOBER 27: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR) questions U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland as he testifies at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing about oversight of the Department of Justice on October 27, 2021 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis-Pool/Getty Images)OAN NEWSROOMUPDATED 2:50 PM PT ‚Äì Monday, July 25, 2022Senator Tom Cotton (R-Ark.) lamented the January 6 show trial is not fair or competitive. In an interview on Monday, Cotton said the Democrat-run panel has ‚Äúno adversarial process‚Äù and it‚Äôs essentially denying due process to its targets.He stressed that there‚Äôs no one on the January 6 committee whose view of the Capitol protest would be different than Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs (D-Calif.). Cotton voiced that the two Republicans on that committee are no different than Democrats in their assessments of those events.‚ÄúThere is no one on that committee who takes a view different from Nancy Pelosi or even a view that‚Äôs like we should examine the full context of all of these statements, of all of these recordings, of all of this video,‚Äù Cotton said. ‚ÄúWe have no idea of the videos and the audio recordings and the testimony is being presented in its full context.‚ÄùHugh Hewitt, the host of the Hugh Hewitt Show asked him ‚ÄúWhat is the principal defect of this committee?‚Äù‚ÄúThat it has no adversarial process whatsoever,‚Äù he replied. ‚ÄúLiz Cheney (Wyo.) and Adam Kinzinger (Ill.), the two Republicans, clearly share the views of the Democrats on the subject of the committee‚Äôs inquiry. If you had someone like Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) or Jim Banks (R-Ind.) on there, not only would they be privy to all the information, but they would be probing that information and probing witnesses to try to get at truth. Which is again what the Anglo-American legal system has done for centuries.‚ÄùMAGA Republicans claim that the J6 committee hearings amount to a ‚Äúshow trial‚Äù. It‚Äôs a prosecutors brief with no one to speak for the other side, etc. Even some supporters of the committee say that in a way it is if not a show trial then a brief, a prosecutors argument.‚Äî Josh Marshall (@joshtpm) July 23, 2022The Arkansas Senator emphasized that January 6 evidence presented by Democrats is mostly lacking context, while Pelosi has yet to release all video footage from the protest.
image_caption: WASHINGTON, DC ‚Äì OCTOBER 27: Sen. Tom Cotton (R-AR) questions U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland as he testifies at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing about oversight of the Department of Justice on October 27, 2021 in Washington, DC. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis-Pool/Getty Images)
